verses.sanskrit: युञ्जन्ति बरध्नमरुषं चरन्तं परि तस्थुषः | रोचन्तेरोचना दिवि ||
verses.transliteration: yuñjanti bradhnamaruṣaṃ carantaṃ pari tasthuṣaḥ | rocanterocanā divi ||
verses.translation: They who stand round him as he moves harness the bright, the ruddy Steed The lights are shining in the sky.
verses.explanation: Describes the harnessing of Indra's chariot by the gods, with lights shining in heaven.

verses.sanskrit: युञ्जन्त्यस्य काम्या हरी विपक्षसा रथे | शोणा धर्ष्णू नर्वाहसा ||
verses.transliteration: yuñjantyasya kāmyā harī vipakṣasā rathe | śoṇā dharṣṇū nṛvāhasā ||
verses.translation: On both sides to the car they yoke the two bay coursers dear to him, Bold, tawny, bearers of the Chief.
verses.explanation: Praises Indra's beloved horses yoked to his chariot, emphasizing their strength and beauty.

verses.sanskrit: केतुं कर्ण्वन्नकेतवे पेशो मर्या अपेशसे | समुषद्भिरजायथाः ||
verses.transliteration: ketuṃ kṛṇvannaketave peśo maryā apeśase | samuṣadbhirajāyathāḥ ||
verses.translation: Thou, making light where no light was, and form, O men: where form was not, Wast born together with the Dawns.
verses.explanation: Celebrates Indra's role in bringing light and form, born alongside the Dawns.

verses.translation: Thereafter they, as is their wont, threw off the state of babes unborn, Assuming sacrificial names.
verses.explanation: Refers to the gods shedding their embryonic state and taking sacrificial identities.

verses.sanskrit: वीळु चिदारुजत्नुभिर्गुहा चिदिन्द्र वह्निभिः | अविन्द उस्रिया अनु ||
verses.transliteration: vīḷu cidārujatnubhirghuhā cidindra vahnibhiḥ | avinda usriyā anu ||
verses.translation: Thou, Indra, with the Tempest-Gods, the breakers down of what is firm, Foundest the kine even in the cave.
verses.explanation: Praises Indra for recovering the cows hidden in the cave with the Maruts.

verses.sanskrit: देवयन्तो यथा मतिमछा विदद्वसुं गिरः | महामनूषत शरुतम ||
verses.transliteration: devayanto yathā matimachā vidadvasuṃ ghiraḥ | mahāmanūṣata śrutam ||
verses.translation: Worshipping even as they list, singers laud him who findeth wealth, The far-renowned, the mighty One.
verses.explanation: Singers praise Indra, who bestows wealth, as they worship according to their will.

verses.sanskrit: इन्द्रेण सं हि दर्क्षसे संजग्मानो अबिभ्युषा | मन्दू समानवर्चसा ||
verses.transliteration: indreṇa saṃ hi dṛkṣase saṃjaghmāno abibhyuṣā | mandū samānavarcasā ||
verses.translation: Mayest thou verily be seen coming by fearless Indra's side: Both joyous, equal in your sheen.
verses.explanation: A prayer to see the sacrificer united with Indra, both joyful and radiant.

verses.translation: With Indra's well beloved hosts, the blameless, hastening to heaven, The sacrificer cries aloud.
verses.explanation: The sacrificer calls out with Indra's beloved, blameless hosts ascending to heaven.

verses.sanskrit: अतः परिज्मन्ना गहि दिवो वा रोचनादधि | समस्मिन्न्र्ञ्जते गिरः ||
verses.transliteration: ataḥ parijmannā gahi divo vā rocanādadhi | samasminnṛñjate ghiraḥ ||
verses.translation: Come from this place, O Wanderer, or downward from the light of heaven: Our songs of praise all yearn for this.
verses.explanation: Invites Indra to come from various places, as the hymns yearn for him.

verses.sanskrit: इतो वा सातिमीमहे दिवो वा पार्थिवादधि | इन्द्रं महोवा रजसः ||
verses.transliteration: ito vā sātimīmahe divo vā pārthivādadhi | indraṃ mahovā rajasaḥ ||
verses.translation: Indra we seek to give us help, from here, from heaven above the earth, Or from the spacious firmament.
verses.explanation: Seeks Indra's help from all directions, emphasizing his omnipresence.

overallTheme: This hymn celebrates Indra's divine chariot, horses, and heroic exploits, including the recovery of stolen cattle and his role in cosmic creation. It emphasizes the reciprocal relationship between the gods and worshippers through hymns and sacrifices.
culturalContext: Vedic hymns to Indra highlight themes of divine intervention, the importance of soma sacrifices, and the symbiotic bond between deities and humans. The Maruts (storm gods) are portrayed as Indra's companions, reflecting the Vedic pantheon's interconnected nature. The hymn's structure moves from description to invocation, mirroring ritual progression.
